natural problem: Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability at least one of the dice shows a 1?
natural solution: There are 5 ways in which the first roll is not 1, and 5 ways in which the second roll is not 1, so there are $5 \times 5 = 25$ ways in which neither die shows 1.
Therefore there are $36-25=11$ ways in which one or both dice show 1.
So the probability of this is $\boxed{\dfrac{11}{36}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes dice1 dice2 :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "dice1 \<in> {1..6} \<and> dice2 \<in> {1..6}"
and h1 : "prob {1..6} = 1"
shows  "prob {(dice1, dice2). dice1 \<in> {1..6} \<and> dice2 \<in> {1..6} \<and> (dice1 = 1 \<or> dice2 = 1)} = 11 / 36"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability at least one of the dice shows a 1? The final Answer is \dfrac{11}{36}
 ### Proof
 There are 5 ways in which the first roll is not 1, and 5 ways in which the second roll is not 1, so there are $5 \times 5 = 25$ ways in which neither die shows 1.
 Therefore there are $36-25=11$ ways in which one or both dice show 1.
 So the probability of this is $\boxed{\dfrac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes dice1 dice2 :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "dice1 \<in> {1..6} \<and> dice2 \<in> {1..6}"
and h1 : "prob {1..6} = 1"
shows  "prob {(dice1, dice2). dice1 \<in> {1..6} \<and> dice2 \<in> {1..6} \<and> (dice1 = 1 \<or> dice2 = 1)} = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Two dice are rolled, each with faces numbered from 1 to 6. What is the probability that at least one of the dice shows a 1? The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = 1 - (5 / 6) powr 2"
shows  "P = 11 / 36"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability at least one of the dice shows a 1? The final Answer is \dfrac{11}{36}
 ### Proof
 There are 5 ways in which the first roll is not 1, and 5 ways in which the second roll is not 1, so there are $5 \times 5 = 25$ ways in which neither die shows 1.
 Therefore there are $36-25=11$ ways in which one or both dice show 1.
 So the probability of this is $\boxed{\dfrac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = 1 - (5 / 6) powr 2"
shows  "P = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the value of $P$ if $P = 1 - \left(\frac{5}{6}\right)^2$. The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> probability n = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "indepEvents (\<lambda> n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6) (\<lambda> n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6)"
shows  "probability (\<lambda> (n, m). (n = 1) \<or> (m = 1)) = 11 / 36"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability at least one of the dice shows a 1? The final Answer is \dfrac{11}{36}
 ### Proof
 There are 5 ways in which the first roll is not 1, and 5 ways in which the second roll is not 1, so there are $5 \times 5 = 25$ ways in which neither die shows 1.
 Therefore there are $36-25=11$ ways in which one or both dice show 1.
 So the probability of this is $\boxed{\dfrac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> probability n = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "indepEvents (\<lambda> n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6) (\<lambda> n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6)"
shows  "probability (\<lambda> (n, m). (n = 1) \<or> (m = 1)) = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a fair six-sided dice roll, the probability of each number from 1 to 6 is $\frac{1}{6}$. If two dice are rolled independently, what is the probability that at least one of them shows a 1? The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "finite P"
and h1 : "card P = 36"
and h2 : "P = { (a, b) | a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> (a = 1 \<or> b = 1) }"
shows  "ereal (card P) / ereal (card ({1..6} \<times> {1..6})) = 11 / 36"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability at least one of the dice shows a 1? The final Answer is \dfrac{11}{36}
 ### Proof
 There are 5 ways in which the first roll is not 1, and 5 ways in which the second roll is not 1, so there are $5 \times 5 = 25$ ways in which neither die shows 1.
 Therefore there are $36-25=11$ ways in which one or both dice show 1.
 So the probability of this is $\boxed{\dfrac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "finite P"
and h1 : "card P = 36"
and h2 : "P = { (a, b) | a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> (a = 1 \<or> b = 1) }"
shows  "ereal (card P) / ereal (card ({1..6} \<times> {1..6})) = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In a set of ordered pairs $(a, b)$, where $a$ and $b$ are integers ranging from 1 to 6, find the probability that either $a$ or $b$ is equal to 1. There are 36 pairs in total. The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: "real"
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<Sum> (x, y) | x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<and> (x = 1 \<or> y = 1) . 1) / 36"
shows  "prob = 11 / 36"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 Therefore there are $36-25=11$ ways in which one or both dice show 1.
 So the probability of this is $\boxed{\dfrac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

fixes prob :: "real"
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<Sum> (x, y) | x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<and> (x = 1 \<or> y = 1) . 1) / 36"
shows  "prob = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: What is the probability of rolling a pair of dice and getting a sum where either one of the dice shows a 1? The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<lambda> x. 1 / 6)"
and h1 : "prob_space.prob_measure (pmf prob) {x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6}"
and h2 : "indep_vars (\<lambda>_. pmf prob) (\<lambda>_. {x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6}) UNIV"
shows  "measure (extend_measure (pmf prob) {x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6}) {(a, b). a = 1 \<or> b = 1} = 11 / 36"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability at least one of the dice shows a 1? The final Answer is \dfrac{11}{36}
 ### Proof
 There are 5 ways in which the first roll is not 1, and 5 ways in which the second roll is not 1, so there are $5 \times 5 = 25$ ways in which neither die shows 1.
 Therefore there are $36-25=11$ ways in which one or both dice show 1.
 So the probability of this is $\boxed{\dfrac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes prob :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<lambda> x. 1 / 6)"
and h1 : "prob_space.prob_measure (pmf prob) {x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6}"
and h2 : "indep_vars (\<lambda>_. pmf prob) (\<lambda>_. {x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6}) UNIV"
shows  "measure (extend_measure (pmf prob) {x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6}) {(a, b). a = 1 \<or> b = 1} = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: A fair six-sided die is rolled twice. What is the probability that at least one of the rolls results in a 1? The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>k. k \<ge> 1 \<and> k \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> probability k = 1/6"
and h1 : "(\<Sum>k = 1..6. probability k) = 1"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>(a, b). a = 1 \<or> b = 1) = 11 / 36"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability at least one of the dice shows a 1? The final Answer is \dfrac{11}{36}
 ### Proof

 Therefore there are $36-25=11$ ways in which one or both dice show 1.
 So the probability of this is $\boxed{\dfrac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>k. k \<ge> 1 \<and> k \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> probability k = 1/6"
and h1 : "(\<Sum>k = 1..6. probability k) = 1"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>(a, b). a = 1 \<or> b = 1) = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In a fair six-sided die roll, each face has a probability of $\frac{1}{6}$ of landing face up. What is the probability that either the first die shows a 1 or the second die shows a 1 (or both) when rolling two dice? The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.
